when i was an undergraduate, i did honors work in a lab focused on organosilicon reaction mechanisms. virtually every synthesis we did started with SiCl4. we made it routinely by the liter using a cylinder of Cl2, passing a very controlled stream over a "heating tape"-wrapped 2" x 12' pyrex tube containing lumps of silicon metal. then we distilled it to purity.

The term "sand" denotes a grain size, not a chemical substance.  The name for the most common natural form of silicone dioxide is 'quartz'.  Silicon polyoxide is also the primary substance in most glass.  Most natural sands do contain quartz, but they also tend to contain grains of feldspar, magnetite, zircon, garnet, and other mineral components, so the term 'sand' as used in the early portion of this video can be misleading.

Industrially SiCl4 is not used to make pure silicon.  SiHCl3 is much better for that use.  SiCl4 is a by-product when you mass produce SiHCl3, which is more of a waste.  Common use of it is to burn the hell out of it and turn it to silica (SiO2).

Hello from the 2019

I used to work with SiCl4 all the time, a very nasty chemical. We reacted it with alcohol (2-EBOH) to make an orthosilicate. After processing, neutralizing and stripping off excess alcohol, it was blended into a range of Coolanol products for EXXON. In fact I made all the Coolanol products for Exxon for over 20 years until my retirement. But getting back to SiCl4, if exposed to air/water massive amounts of HCL would be produced. Getting it sprayed on 35 to 40% of your skin would be fatal, because it absorbs so quickly into the skin and acidifies the blood.

You might enjoy making titanium tetrachloride.  It's a lot more volatile and reacts with moisture in the air quickly, so just a few drops produce a dense white smoke of fine titanium dioxide particles.  My impression is that it's safer because the dense smoke is so visible, it's easy to avoid breathing, and it's hard to breathe in unreacted TiCl4 because the reaction with moisture in the air is so prompt.  I don't think there's that much danger in the HCl in the air because it's so dilute.  Of course, breathing the fine TiO2 dust isn't good, the particles are so fine they will never come out.  The problem with SiCl4 is that the reaction with d water is much slower, so you can get some in your eyes where it can produce sheets of glass instead of more easily washed out submicron dust.

Maybe it's not very interesting for a video but did you try to use SiCl4 to create very pure silica (fumed silica) through reaction with oxygen and hydrogen at high temperatures? I'm not sure how the reaction goes, it the Si reacts directly with the oxygen or through the water formed in the reaction. That process is used to created very pure silica that is then used to make "quartz" glass. That kind of silica can be sinterized to create the glass under pressure without needing the extremely high temperatures to make quartz glass by melting sand without any flux. It's also the base for the process to create optical fibers.
It was created James Franklin Hyde and led to the creation of Dow Corning.
Making the glass would be tough but the silica not so much I believe. You would need an oxy-hydro torch burning a stream of SiCl4.
Hyde, U.S. Patent 2,272,342, "Method of making a transparent article of silica"
There are drawings there and at wikipedia in the page for Fumed Silica.
I'm just brainstorming here but that could eventually lead to an way to make some low quality optical fibers at your home lab.

When you use those chlorine tablets, you're introducing cyanuric acid into your experiments. Cyanuric acid is a "stabilizer" for chlorine in solution, to help it survive exposure to sunlight/UV in an outdoor pool situation.

Just something to consider.

nilered what did you study?

In my work, which involved spectroscopy in the UV wavelength range, I needed to use sample containers with extremely pure silica windows.  Silica windows used for UV-Vis spectroscopy would not do because impurities in silica made from sand absorb in the shorter wavelength UV.  I'm told the silica was made from silane (SiH4, the gaseous silicon analog of methane.) and oxygen.  Since silane is used in the semiconductor industry to generate thin layers of precisely doped high purity silicon, it was available in in quantity at absurdly pure grades (like 99.99999 % or something like that).  As long as very pure oxygen is used, a very pure silica is the result.  I'd like to know how the ultrapure silica is handled - melted, formed, ground & polished etc. - without contaminating it.  Molten glass and silicates can corrode most metals.  Fiberglass is produced using spinnerets of platinum metals, for eg.  I suppose the same goes for pure silica.  Maybe not, but the industrial process still intrigues me.

I know this is an old video, but it just occurred to me that Iron is a common contaminant in silicon. The red contaminate you filtered from the SiCl4 may have been mostly iron chloride. I have reacted iron with chlorine gas before and it looks exactly this. The red deposits on the reaction tube and suspension you collected look very much like iron chloride.

Inorganic and organic perchlorate chemistry
Synthesis of hydrazoic acid, hydrazine hydrate (or hydrazine salts) and sulphur nitrides
Solvated electron demo (an alkali metal dissolved in anhydrous NH3) and application in a Birch Reduction.

I have a few suggestions, but please take care, as some of my suggested experiments involve the production of particularly hazardous and difficult to handle chemicals:
Inorganic and organic perchlorate chemistry

Your SiCl4 preparation reminds me of my final year project for my chemistry degree, which involved working with Al isopropoxide, which hydrolyses in the presence of moisture much like SiCl4 does. My project involved the Sol Gel synthesis of Ba, Co, Fe and Cu-doped alumina foam supports for catalytic applications, e.g. in space thrusters employing a nitrous oxide/CH4 oxidant-fuel and greenhouse gas (specifically, CH4) abatement. The expanded alumina foams were produced by incorporating a carbohydrate (sucrose) into Al isopropoxide (which is viscous and gel-like), adding aqueous solutions (containing dopant metal species in the form of water-soluble salts; e.g. Ba(NO3)2) to hydrolyse and form finely divided alumina, then calcining the matrix at over 1000 degrees C to sinter the alumina and also oxidise the sucrose to CO2 gas, which expanded the alumna matrix to form a sintered alumina foam with a very high surface area. Maybe this will inspire you to try out a Sol Gel preparation?
